title: SB 182
content: The people of California enact the following. The Second Validating Act of 2015, also known as Section 1, defines "public body" as various state departments, agencies, boards, commissions, and local entities. This includes air pollution control districts, airport districts, assessment districts, and bridge and highway districts. Various local entities are included in the definition of "public body" in the Second Validating Act of 2015, such as California water districts, city maintenance districts, community college districts, and county transportation commissions. Various local entities are considered as "public bodies" under the Second Validating Act of 2015, including county water authorities, drainage districts, fire protection districts, housing authorities, and library districts, among others. Various local entities such as irrigation districts, joint highway districts, library districts, local health care districts, and nonprofit corporations are considered as "public bodies" under the Second Validating Act of 2015. Various types of districts and authorities are considered as "public bodies" under the Second Validating Act of 2015, including protection districts, public utility districts, school districts, sewer districts, transit districts, and more. The Second Validating Act of 2015 includes various types of districts and authorities as "public bodies," such as toll tunnel authorities, transit development boards, water agencies, and wine grape pest and disease control districts. It excludes community redevelopment agencies and community development commissions from this definition. The curr_chunk defines "Bonds" as instruments of indebtedness incurred by public bodies for public purposes. "Hereafter" refers to any time after the effective date of the act. SEC. 3 declares all public bodies previously organized under any law to be legally functioning with rights and obligations. SEC. 4 confirms the boundaries of public bodies as previously established. SEC. 5 validates the boundaries shown on maps or plats used by the assessor. SEC. 5 confirms and validates all past actions taken by public bodies regarding annexation, inclusion, detachment, consolidation, merger, or dissolution of territories or public bodies. SEC. 6 authorizes, confirms, and validates all past actions related to the issuance of bonds by public bodies for public purposes. All bonds issued by public bodies are legally binding obligations, whether previously issued, awarded and sold, authorized by ordinance, resolution, order, or through election. Bonds authorized by a public body through election are legally binding obligations when issued and delivered in accordance with that authorization. SEC. 7 of this act validates acts and proceedings previously taken under legislative authorization, limited by the California and United States Constitutions. It does not legalize any contested matters in legal proceedings within 30 days of the act's effective date. SEC. 8 of the act does not authorize or legalize any act, proceeding, or contract that has been previously determined to be illegal or void. Any challenge to the validity of actions taken under laws for the formation, organization, or changes to public bodies must be filed within six months of the effective date of this act. Otherwise, such actions will be considered valid and legally binding. This act does not extend the time limit for legal action beyond what is already barred by statutes of limitations or laches. The curr_chunk discusses the time limit for legal action, extending it beyond the existing statute of limitations. The curr_chunk clarifies that the creation or boundary changes of public bodies must be filed in accordance with specific government code sections for assessment or taxation purposes. It also states that the act is urgent for validating public bodies promptly.
